author: Виктория Джамалова
title: Детский сад №16 в Апрелевке могут сдать позже срока
text:
В детском саду № 16 в Апрелевке в настоящее время проходит капитальный ремонт, который должен завершиться к сентябрю. Однако по итогам недавнего осмотра, проведенного заместителем председателя Московской областной Думы Олегом Рожновым, стало очевидно, что работы отстают от графика.
Во время визита Олег Рожнов встретился с подрядчиком и обсудил текущие проблемы. Он отметил, что не все строительные материалы были завезены на объект, а темпы выполнения работ вызывают серьезные опасения. В связи с этим зампред поделился своими опасениями с Романом Суровцевым, представителем Дирекции заказчика капитального строительства. Они договорились, что Роман Суровцев посетит объект в тот же день, чтобы оценить ситуацию и совместно принять необходимые решения.
На данный момент на объекте завершены демонтажные работы, продолжаются внутренние отделочные работы. Ведется монтаж внутренних коммуникаций.
Несмотря на текущие трудности, все заинтересованные стороны работают над тем, чтобы минимизировать задержки и обеспечить открытие детского сада в срок.
Капитальный ремонт завершат к новому учебному году, здесь отремонтируют инженерные коммуникации, внутренние помещения, поставят новую мебель, также благоустроят прилегающую территорию.
На время проведения ремонтных работ дети устроены в другие образовательные учреждения по месту жительства.
Ранее сообщалось, что в Апрелевке построили современную котельную для больницы.

author: Redacción ELHERALDO.CO
title: La Roca Sánchez reveló que sufrió de racismo en Inglater
text:
Todavía hay cenizas en el fuego que encendió la polémica de Enzo Fernández, jugador de Argentina, cuando en un live de Instagram celebró con cánticos calificados como racistas el triunfo de su selección en la Copa América. Sugerimos: Pepe anuncia su retiro del fútbol profesional a sus 41 años En el autobús, tras haber ganado la Copa América, Fernández transmitió en vivo cómo era la celebración de los jugadores de la 'Albiceleste', que entre sus cánticos, entonaron una letra diseñada para aquella final del 2018 entre franceses y argentinos. Fernández cantaba, específicamente, sobre el origen africano de varios jugadores de la selección francesa, lo que dio pie a una serie de acusaciones de racismo que cayeron en los hombros del mediocampista. De interés: Luis Javier Mosquera lo dejó todo en levantamiento de pesas Como consecuencia, varios compañeros de Fernández expresaron su inconformidad con la actitud del jugador del Chelsea, que días después debió pedir disculpas ante lo ocurrido.Tras ese escándalo, las semanas han pasado y, en las últimas horas, el periodista argentino Hugo Balsassone publicó una entrevista con el mediocampista colombiano Carlos Sánchez, quien no perdió la oportunidad de referirse a los acontecimientos antes mencionados a raíz de una pregunta direccionada a saber si en algún momento había sido víctima de racismo. Recomendamos: Miguel Ángel Borja podría perderse los octavos de final de Copa Libertadores “Fue un movimiento que se armó, pero estoy segurísimo que Enzo se lleva súper bien con todo el mundo. Muchas veces es desde la ignorancia, lo dijo pero no estaba pensando en eso”, aseguró Sánchez en un intento de defensa hacia el mediocampista argentino de 23 años. Y añadió: “Tendrían que haberle dicho: ‘¿Cómo vas a decir eso?’. Ponerlo en redes me pareció más grave que lo que hizo Enzo. Ahí se desencadenaron 50 mil cosas: temas políticos entre países. Con un simple gesto se evitaba todo eso. Dentro del fútbol estás generando violencia. Va a haber gente de Francia que antes veía a Enzo como un jugador y ahora lo va a odiar. Somos conductores de muchas cosas en el fútbol, nos sigue mucha gente. Este tipo de cosas las podemos evitar con otra manera de relacionarse”.La Roca Sánchez me contó que sufrió racismo en el fútbol de Inglaterra pero que no le afecta y aprovechó para reflexionar por lo sucedido entre Enzo Fernández y Fofana.
La nota completa la pueden encontrar en mi canal: https://t.co/RVYLWTG6Pd https://t.co/oirH0fc77J pic.twitter.com/6DHI876eFQ

author: Brieanna Charlebois; The Canadian Press
title: B.C. odour incidents spark questions around corporate ethics and communication
text: Vancouver resident Robert Ford was heading to a yoga class Sunday morning when he smelled an odour he likened to "semi-burnt fuel." As a member of council at his Kitsilano apartment building, he said he decided to check the boiler room, but it smelled fine. "I was expecting something in there, so that was strange. I scratched my head and I went to the front door, which is right across from the beach, and it was 10 times more powerful outside," he said. He immediately began searching online for an explanation but didn't find any answers until almost four hours later. "I'm just kind of perplexed at how we can have such a nasty event with no public information hardly," he said. It was one of two acrid odours that spread over parts of Metro Vancouver in less than a week, raising questions about corporate responsibility to inform the public when such events cause widespread concern and confusion but fall short of health and safety breaches. The smell Ford referred to was revealed to be "an unplanned issue" with a Parkland fuel refinery processing unit in neighbouring Burnaby. The heavy stench, which Ford compared to jet fuel, blanketed parts of Metro Vancouver and caused more than 100 complaints from local residents. It came just days after a "controlled release of gas" from a FortisBC interconnect station in nearby Delta, B.C., prompted criticisms from Mayor George Harvie and numerous residents that the utility didn't notify the public for more than four hours. Harvie said the heavy odour caused stress and panic in the community, and a flood of calls to local police and fire departments hampered Delta's emergency response services. A statement from Fortis said it was investigating after an elevated level of the odorant added to natural gas was unknowingly sent out in a controlled release of gas. Carol Liao, a University of B.C. Sauder fellow at the Dhillon centre for business ethics, said these incidents are not necessarily matters for legislation, but rather about accountability and ethics. "Businesses obviously need to obey bylaws, but they also need to understand that beyond that, there is a need to act responsibly to maintain public trust," she said. "If a business is the cause of a terrible odour that's impacting the surrounding community and beyond, it should act as a good corporate citizen and own up to the problem right away, alert public officials, alert those possibly impacted and in harm's way, mitigate the damage and be accountable." Harvie said he was involved in both incidents as Delta's mayor and as chair of Metro Vancouver's regional district. "The difference between the two was (in) Metro Vancouver, air quality inspectors were on scene at the refinery, so we had more accurate information being fed back to us," he said. Metro Vancouver monitors emissions of particulates, nitrogen dioxide and sulphur dioxide from the Parkland refinery, and the district has said air quality objectives for the contaminants weren't exceeded Sunday. But, Harvie said the Fortis incident was different. "The one from Fortis was very disturbing to me and it does speak a lot about corporate values (and) corporate responsibilities. They kept the information away from us," he said. "This was just unacceptable." Harvie took to the social media site X after the smell covered an area stretching from the Tsawwassen ferry terminal to more than 30 kilometres away in Vancouver. The mayor said he had contacted FortisBC requesting an urgent followup meeting. The Fortis statement released on Wednesday said work was being performed on new equipment, which was not connected to the gas system, and while a controlled release of gas was planned, the release of odour was not. "Further review is underway to determine why there was an elevated level of odorant in the equipment," it said. "Although the controlled release of gas at the interconnect station on Jan. 16 contained an elevated level of this odorant, it is not harmful and there are no immediate or long-term health effects." Fortis said it had been in contact with local First Nations, municipal and emergency officials, including Harvie, as well as government regulators, to provide information on its response. "We have also started a review of the incident and are working with relevant stakeholders during this process." Kevin Farrow, technical director of Parkland, said in an interview that the refinery had paused processing operations earlier this month due to extreme cold weather. "It was during that restart of the refinery, that one of the processing units had a plugged line, which ultimately led to the plume and odour that many experienced on Sunday," he said. "We've launched a review to better understand the root cause of what happened and how we got into this situation." Parkland had issued an advisory on its website two days before the plume, alerting people who live nearby that they may notice noise and "higher than usual flare" from the facility. In a timeline created by the refinery and sent to The Canadian Press, the company said the incident happened around 7:30 a.m. Sunday. It said Metro Vancouver had been notified by 8:30 a.m., and by 9 a.m., the Burnaby Fire Department and the RCMP had created a perimeter around the facility as a safety precaution. The RCMP was called off at 11:26 a.m., while the fire department remained in place until 3:15 p.m., the timeline said. The refinery's first public statement Sunday was issued at 11 a.m., notifying the public of an incident that cause elevated smoke, odours and particulate matter. That was followed up at 12:30 p.m. with a media advisory, announcing the shut down of operations. While some, including Ford in Kitsilano, believe communication needs to come sooner to alleviate panic, Farrow said the "priority" of the refinery is to "communicate accurate and confirmed information to the public." "We have that information now," he said. "We understand more, and we've begun to reach out to our community partners and to our neighbours, (and) you can expect a lot more information from the refinery in the coming days and weeks." Farrow noted the refinery remains shut down but the company announced it would be conducting a "controlled and necessary operational procedure" on Thursday. "We do not expect any impacts of the community. We're just making them aware, just in case anything were to occur," Farrow said. Metro Vancouver also issued an updated air quality bulletin Wednesday night, saying it "will be closely monitoring" as the refinery conducts the operation "that may result in odour, smoke and flaring." While some residents expressed concern about the announcement online, Liao applauded the move, saying an advanced public statement can be "immensely helpful in ensuring transparency and accountability to the surrounding communities." "It helps avoid any public confusion and the tying up of resources such as 911 calls, while also mitigating risk," she said. This report by The Canadian Press was first published Jan. 25, 2024. Brieanna Charlebois, The Canadian Press Note to readers: This is a corrected story. A previous version said there was a gas leak at a FortisBC plant.

author: Voleer Thomas, Gainesville Sun
title: NE Gainesville charter school students honor Black history month
text: Boulware Springs Charter School fourth- and fifth-grade students presented themselves as significant Black figures during a Black History Month program held Wednesday at the school in northeast Gainesville. The program was the end result of a Black history research project celebration at the school at 1303 NE 23rd Ave. The Black History Month program has grown to include all of the grades instead of students from one grade showcasing a Black History Wax Museum, said Cecile Wicks, the school's assistant director. “It’s been great because we can include all grades,” Wicks said. “Every time we have an event, we get a community celebration. The community is very proud and the parents are excited.” The event allows students to show what they've learned about Black history to their parents and they get to bond together while learning more about Black history, Wicks said. “It gives kids a chance to be outgoing, share their PowerPoint, dress up and incorporate their artwork,” Wicks said. “It’s an important time for family and kids. Parents get to walk around with their kids to see the presentations.” Fourth- and fifth-grade students dressed up as historical Black figures during their presentation as visitors walked to each table around the walkway outside of the school. Black history: Black heroes from history come alive at Boulware Springs Charter School 'wax museum' Third-graders recorded themselves talking about historical Black figures while attendees listened to the recordings through headphones. First- and second-graders participated in a Folktale Lane project where they told stories from the book titled, “Mufaro’s Beautiful Daughters: An African Tale.” Kindergartners and all the other grades participated in an “I Have A Dream” writing exercise where they shared what their dream was with their black silhouette that was cut out to accompany what they wrote. The collaboration between the teachers over the past few months helped make the event a success, said Tiffany White, director of the school. “The kids have a really rich experience because of that,” White said. “We have huge parent involvement. What they learn at school, the parents constantly include it at home. This project is deep and it takes the help of everyone.” Elaina Townsend is in the fourth grade and dressed up as Bessie Coleman during her Black History Month presentation. Coleman was the first Black woman to obtain a pilot license. “I like this a lot because we get to learn new things,” Townsend said. Destiny McRae is a fourth grade teacher who helped her students with their presentations and was amazed to see the results. “It gave me a chance to be creative and it gave our students a chance to learn more about their history,” McRae said. “It is important because to know why we have certain things and rights we have now, we have to know our history so we know how to improve them.” Shari Johnson came to see the work of her daughter Tiarra Anderson during the Black History Month presentation. Anderson researched Laila Ali, a retired professional woman boxer who held several middleweight titles and is the daughter of the late heavyweight boxing champion and Black icon Muhammad Ali. “It’s really educational,” Johnson said. “You can tell the students knew their stuff.” Kimberly Hale, a parent of two students at the charter school, said she enjoyed seeing the students share what they learned during their research. “It encourages me to keep fighting and helps me to keep pushing for positivity and change, “ Hale said. “It was inspiring to hear what they had to say. I enjoyed getting the information from the children. This is a reminder to ourselves of what our ancestors have been through.”

organizations.name: ne 23rd ave. the black history month
